title: Native Life in the Philippines
notes: The curated aesthetic of "primitive" Filipinos.

title: Ang Tanging Ina
notes: The movie is an amalgamation of everything that is good and bad with Filipino culture.

title: Batang West Side
notes: Lav Diaz's use of long shots makes the viewer have a more personal connection with the movie.

title: Headhunter's Daughter
notes: The cinematography of the movie encourages the viewer to feel at home while watching.

title: Anak Dalita
notes: The setting of the movie paints a very authentic image of the life in Manila after the war.

title: Genghis Khan
notes: Manuel Conde's mastery of production is in full display here in successfully creating the feeling of being in Mongolia.

title: Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag
notes: Lino Brocka has amazingly depicted a "way of seeing" of Manila from the perspective of Filipinos from the provinces.

title: Kisapmata
notes: The subtle horror is very strong and effective in this movie.

title: Dagitab
notes: The movie bravely explores themes that are not usually covered in popular Filipino media.

title: Filipi√±ana
notes: The stillness and choreographed nature of the film is a good representation of the everyday lives of the ordinary Filipino.

title: Agapito
notes: Despite being a short film, the movie was able to build up to create multiple exposition points.

title: It's Raining Frogs Outside
notes: The movie successfully capitalized on creating a nostalgic feeling to create a connection.

title: Juan Gapang
notes: The movie creatively contrasts the roughness of urban versus rural life in the Philippines.

title: ABCD
notes: Using easily digestible media such as cartoons as means to expose should be explored more in Filipino cinema.

title: Oliver
notes: It is very interesting to have the documentary show very personal aspects of Oliver's life.

title: Mababangong Bangungot
notes: Kidlat Tahimik was able to create a very authentic community as if the viewer is part of it while watching.

title: Bloom Where You Are Planted
notes: The movie did not limit itself to a single medium and incorporated different mediums to improve its storytelling.

title: Aguila
notes: Muslim Mindanao being part of the movie is great and it showed the reality of the region at the time.

title: Pieta
notes: The movie was really effective in making the viewers hate Rigor.

title: Manila By Night
notes: In the movie, it is shown that Manila does not really sleep at night but during the day.

title: Kinatay
notes: The use of natural lighting in the scenes makes the movie feel like a documentary.

title: Merika
notes: Challenging the popular American dream that Filipinos have by showing the unfortunate reality of OFW.

title: Astri Maka si Tambulah
notes: Uses long close up shots to better show the emotions of the characters.

title: Sanctissima
notes: Food in storytelling is very important, and in this movie it made sure that it looked as grotesque as possible.

title: Hondo
notes: The movie felt like it is in a constant state of subtle panic.

title: Lola Loleng
notes: The unconventional animation used in the movie allowed the creators to use a huge selection of colors in creating the mood for each scene.

title: Baguio Address No. 10
notes: The use of old family videos and lofi audio narration creates a very nostalgic and personal connection with the film.

title: Women of the Weeping River
notes: The movie created a painfully honest portrayal of what life is like in Sulu.

title: Bayaning Third World
notes: Sticking with black and white in the movie tells us that whether Rizal retracted or not is a yes or no question.
